Copy of arithmetic.Description: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.
Copy of arithmetic.Title: Number opposites
Copy of arithmetic.Translated Description: Opposite numbers are the same distance from 0 on opposite sides of the number line. A number opposite is sometimes called an additive inverse.

Copy of arithmetic.Description: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.7, 6.NS.C.7c, 6.NS.C.7d

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
If you're looking to create an army of robot dogs, will it really make a difference if you have 10,300 dogs, 9,997 dogs or 10,005 dogs?  Probably not.  All you really care about is how many dogs you have to, say, the nearest thousand (10,000 dogs).

In this tutorial, we'll learn about conventions for rounding whole numbers.  Very useful when we might not need to (or cannot) be completely precise.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Rounding whole numbers
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description:
If you're looking to create an army of robot dogs, will it really make a difference if you have 10,300 dogs, 9,997 dogs or 10,005 dogs?  Probably not.  All you really care about is how many dogs you have to, say, the nearest thousand (10,000 dogs).

In this tutorial, we'll learn about conventions for rounding whole numbers.  Very useful when we might not need to (or cannot) be completely precise.
Copy of pre-algebra.Document Merge Status - Lab Topics: Data merged and appended successfully; Manually run by jason.kilpatrick@ccd.edu; Timestamp: Jan 21 2018 5:14 AM

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: Regrouping involves taking value from one place and giving it to another.  It is a great way to make sure you understand place value.  It is also super useful when subtracting multi-digit numbers (the process is often called "borrowing" even though you never really "pay back" the value taken from one place and given to another).
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Regrouping whole numbers
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: Regrouping involves taking value from one place and giving it to another.  It is a great way to make sure you understand place value.  It is also super useful when subtracting multi-digit numbers (the process is often called "borrowing" even though you never really "pay back" the value taken from one place and given to another).
Copy of pre-algebra.Document Merge Status - Lab Topics: Data merged and appended successfully; Manually run by jason.kilpatrick@ccd.edu; Timestamp: Jan 21 2018 5:14 AM

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: If you have the expression "3 + 4 x 5", do you add the 3 to the 4 first or multiply the 4 and 5 first?  To clear up confusion here, the math world has defined which operation should get priority over others.  This is super important.  You won't really be able to do any involved math if you don't get this clear.  But don't worry, this tutorial has your back.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Order of operations
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: If you have the expression "3 + 4 x 5", do you add the 3 to the 4 first or multiply the 4 and 5 first?  To clear up confusion here, the math world has defined which operation should get priority over others.  This is super important.  You won't really be able to do any involved math if you don't get this clear.  But don't worry, this tutorial has your back.
Copy of pre-algebra.Document Merge Status - Lab Topics: Data merged and appended successfully; Manually run by jason.kilpatrick@ccd.edu; Timestamp: Jan 21 2018 5:14 AM

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
2 + 3 = 3 + 2, 6 x 4 = 4 x 6.  Adding zero to a number does not change the number.  Likewise, multiplying a number by 1 does not change it.

You may already know these things from working through other tutorials, but some people (not us) like to give these properties names that sound far more complicated than the property themselves.  This tutorial (which we're not a fan of), is here just in case you're asked to identify the "Commutative Law of Multiplication".   We believe the important thing isn't the fancy label, but the underlying idea (which isn't that fancy).
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Arithmetic properties
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description:
2 + 3 = 3 + 2, 6 x 4 = 4 x 6.  Adding zero to a number does not change the number.  Likewise, multiplying a number by 1 does not change it.

You may already know these things from working through other tutorials, but some people (not us) like to give these properties names that sound far more complicated than the property themselves. Copy of pre-algebra.Description: The distributive property is an idea that shows up over and over again in mathematics.  It is the idea that 5 x (3 + 4) = (5 x 3) + (5 x 4).  If that last statement made complete sense, no need to watch this tutorial.  If it didn't or you don't know why it's true, then this tutorial might be a good way to pass the time :)
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Distributive property
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: The distributive property is an idea that shows up over and over again in mathematics.  It is the idea that 5 x (3 + 4) = (5 x 3) + (5 x 4).  If that last statement made complete sense, no need to watch this tutorial.  If it didn't or you don't know why it's true, then this tutorial might be a good way to pass the time :)

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number.  This will be useful throughout our study of math.  Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key!  Eye of the tiger!
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Factors and multiples
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: In this tutorial, we'll begin to think about the numbers that "make up" the number.  This will be useful throughout our study of math.  Whether we are adding fractions, exploring mystical number patterns, or breaking computer codes, factoring numbers are key!  Eye of the tiger!

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously).  They are both basic and mysterious.  The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place.  This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Prime numbers
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: Prime numbers have been studied by mathematicians and mystics for ages (seriously).  They are both basic and mysterious.  The more you explore them, the more you will realize that the universe is a fascinating place.  This tutorial will introduce you to the magical world of prime numbers.

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: You know what prime numbers are and how to identify them.  In this tutorial, we'll see that *all* positive whole numbers can be broken down into products of prime numbers (In some way, prime numbers are the "atoms" of the number world that can be multiplied to create any other number).  Besides being a fascinating idea, it is also extremely useful.  Prime factorization can be used to decrypt encrypted information!
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Prime factorization
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: You know what prime numbers are and how to identify them.  In this tutorial, we'll see that *all* positive whole numbers can be broken down into products of prime numbers (In some way, prime numbers are the "atoms" of the number world that can be multiplied to create any other number).  Besides being a fascinating idea, it is also extremely useful.  Prime factorization can be used to decrypt encrypted information!

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: Life is good, but it can always get better.  Just imagine being able to find the smallest number that is a multiple of two other numbers!  Other than making your life more fulfilling, it will allow you to do incredible things like adding fractions.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Least common multiple
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: Life is good, but it can always get better.  Just imagine being able to find the smallest number that is a multiple of two other numbers!  Other than making your life more fulfilling, it will allow you to do incredible things like adding fractions.

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: You know how to find factors of a number.  But what about factors that are common to two numbers?  Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers.   I know.  Too exciting!
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Greatest common factor
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: You know how to find factors of a number.  But what about factors that are common to two numbers?  Even better, imagine the largest factors that are common to two numbers.   I know.  Too exciting!

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: You'll find absolute value absolutely straightforward--it is just the "distance from zero". If you have a positive number, it is its own absolute value. If you have a negative number, just make it positive to get the absolute value. As you see as you develop mathematically, this idea will eventually extended to more contexts and dimensions, so super important that you understand this core concept now.  Common Core Standards: 6.NS.C.7, 6.NS.C.7c, 6.NS.C.7d

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
Equality is usually a good thing, but the world is not a perfect place.  No matter how hard we try, we can't help but compare one thing to another and realize how unequal they may be.

This tutorial gives you the tools to do these comparisons in the mathematical world (which we call inequalities).  You'll become familiar with the "greater than" and "less than symbols" and learn to use them.

Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Inequalities: Greater than and less than basics

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Exponents
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description:
Addition was nice.  Multiplication was cooler.  In the mood for a new operation that grows numbers even faster?  Ever felt like expressing repeated multiplication with less writing?  Ever wanted to describe how most things in the universe grow and shrink?  Well, exponents are your answer!

This tutorial covers everything from basic exponents to negative and fractional ones.  It assumes you remember your multiplication, negative numbers and fractions.

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical.  What is it?  How does it relate to exponents?  How is the square root different than the cube root?  How can I simplify, multiply and add these things?  

This tutorial assumes you know the basics of exponents and exponent properties and takes you through the radical world for radicals (and gives you some good practice along the way)!
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Square roots
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description:
A strong contender for coolest symbol in mathematics is the radical.  What is it?  How does it relate to exponents?  How is the square root different than the cube root?  How can I simplify, multiply and add these things?  

This tutorial assumes you know the basics of exponents and exponent properties and takes you through the radical world for radicals (and gives you some good practice along the way)!

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: If you're familiar with the idea of a square root, we're about to take things one step (dimension?) further with the cube root.  This generally refers to finding a number that, when cubed, is equal to the number that you're trying to find the cube root of!
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Cube roots
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: If you're familiar with the idea of a square root, we're about to take things one step (dimension?) further with the cube root.  This generally refers to finding a number that, when cubed, is equal to the number that you're trying to find the cube root of!

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
Tired of hairy exponent expressions?  Feel compelled to clean them up?  Well, this tutorial might just give you the tools you need.

If you know a bit about exponents, you'll learn a ton more in this tutorial as you learn about the rules for simplifying exponents.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Exponent properties
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description:
Tired of hairy exponent expressions?  Feel compelled to clean them up?  Well, this tutorial might just give you the tools you need.

If you know a bit about exponents, you'll learn a ton more in this tutorial as you learn about the rules for simplifying exponents.

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents.  And fractional exponents are even more fun.

This idea will open up entirely new vistas to your mathematical life.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Negative exponents
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description:
It's normally a bad idea to hang around with negative people or do negative things, but we think it's OK to associate with negative exponents.  And fractional exponents are even more fun.

This idea will open up entirely new vistas to your mathematical life.

Copy of pre-algebra.Description:
Scientists and engineers often have to deal with super huge (like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000) and super small numbers (like 0.0000000000532) .  How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits?  The answer is to use scientific notation.

If you come to this tutorial with a basic understanding of positive and negative exponents, it should leave you with a new appreciation for representing really huge and really small numbers!
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Scientific notation
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description:
Scientists and engineers often have to deal with super huge (like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000) and super small numbers (like 0.0000000000532) .  How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits?  The answer is to use scientific notation.

If you come to this tutorial with a basic understanding of positive and negative exponents, it should leave you with a new appreciation for representing really huge and really small numbers!

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: When people want to think about the general size of things but not worry about the exact number, they tend to think in terms of "orders of magnitude".  This allows us to analyze and make comparisons between numbers very quickly, which allows us to make decisions about them quickly as well.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Orders of magnitude
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: When people want to think about the general size of things but not worry about the exact number, they tend to think in terms of "orders of magnitude".  This allows us to analyze and make comparisons between numbers very quickly, which allows us to make decisions about them quickly as well.

Copy of pre-algebra.Description: You already understand what scientific notation is.  Now you'll actually use it to compute values and solve real-world problems.
Copy of pre-algebra.Title: Computing with scientific notation
Copy of pre-algebra.Translated Description: You already understand what scientific notation is.  Now you'll actually use it to compute values and solve real-world problems.

Copy of algebra basics.Description: Scientists and engineers often deal with super huge numbers like 6,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 and super small numbers like 0.0000000000532. How can they do this without tiring their hands out?  How can they look at a number and understand how large or small it is without counting the digits? The answer to both questions: scientific notation.

Copy of algebra basics.Title: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares
Copy of algebra basics.Translated Description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

Copy of algebra basics.Description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x+6x+9 as (x+3). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x+28x+49 as (2x+7).
Copy of algebra basics.Title: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares
Copy of algebra basics.Translated Description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x+6x+9 as (x+3). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x+28x+49 as (2x+7).

Copy of algebra.Description: Practice solving word problems that involve a variety of units.

Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Practice solving word problems that involve a variety of units.

Copy of algebra.Description: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true.
Copy of algebra.Title: Two-variable linear equations intro
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Understand what a solution to an equation really means. Practice plugging in values for variables to see whether or not an equation is true.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.
Copy of algebra.Title: x-intercepts and y-intercepts
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about intercepts and practice finding them from graphs, tables, and equations.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.
Copy of algebra.Title: Slope
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about slope (the steepness of a line) and how to find it.

Copy of algebra.Description: You know what horizontal and vertical lines are, but how do their equations look? And what is their slope? Learn all about it in this tutorial.
Copy of algebra.Title: Horizontal & vertical lines
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: You know what horizontal and vertical lines are, but how do their equations look? And what is their slope? Learn all about it in this tutorial.

Copy of algebra.Description: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.
Copy of algebra.Title: Intro to slope-intercept form
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Make an introduction with the most common form of linear equations, slope-intercept form! For example, y=3x+5 is a linear equation in slope-intercept form.

Copy of algebra.Title: Graphing slope-intercept equations
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to graph linear equations that are given in slope-intercept form. For example, graph y=2x+3.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).
Copy of algebra.Title: Writing slope-intercept equations
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to write the equation of a line (in slope-intercept form) when given the graph of the equation or two points on the line. For example, write the equation of the line that passes through the points (0,1) and (5,4).

Copy of algebra.Description: Take an overview of the three main forms of linear equations: slope-intercept, point-slope, and standard. Learn which form is most appropriate for different uses.

Copy of algebra.Title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function

Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Introduction to the domain and range of a function

Copy of algebra.Title: Intervals where a function is positive, negative, increasing, or decreasing

Copy of algebra.Title: Constructing linear models for real-world relationships

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. Evaluate arithmetic sequences.
Copy of algebra.Title: Introduction to arithmetic sequences
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about arithmetic sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common difference. Evaluate arithmetic sequences.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence.
Copy of algebra.Title: Constructing arithmetic sequences
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of an arithmetic sequence.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio. Evaluate geometric sequences.
Copy of algebra.Title: Introduction to geometric sequences
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about geometric sequences and their main features, the initial term and the common ratio. Evaluate geometric sequences.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of a geometric sequence.
Copy of algebra.Title: Constructing geometric sequences
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to find the explicit or recursive formula of a geometric sequence.

Copy of algebra.Description: Now that we've mastered arithmetic and geometric sequences, let's see how they can help us solve real-world word problems. In this tutorial you will find the formula for a sequence that models a real-world relationship.
Copy of algebra.Title: Modeling with sequences
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Now that we've mastered arithmetic and geometric sequences, let's see how they can help us solve real-world word problems. In this tutorial you will find the formula for a sequence that models a real-world relationship.

Copy of algebra.Description: Arithmetic and geometric sequences are very useful, but they are definitely not the only kinds of sequences out there. Let's zoom out and consider some other kinds of sequences.
Copy of algebra.Title: General sequences
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Arithmetic and geometric sequences are very useful, but they are definitely not the only kinds of sequences out there. Let's zoom out and consider some other kinds of sequences.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn what "systems of equations" are, what counts as a solution to such a system, and how we can use graphs to solve them.
Copy of algebra.Title: Introduction to systems of equations
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn what "systems of equations" are, what counts as a solution to such a system, and how we can use graphs to solve them.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method
Copy of algebra.Title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about the elimination method, which is a way manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them algebraically. This is actually very similar to the way we manipulate single equations in order to solve them!
Copy of algebra.Translated Standalone Title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method
Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Equivalent systems of equations and the elimination method

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
Copy of algebra.Title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about the substitution method, which is another way to manipulate systems of equations in order to solve them.
Copy of algebra.Translated Standalone Title: Solving systems of equations with substitution
Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Solving systems of equations with substitution

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=0, express a*b in terms of b alone.
Copy of algebra.Title: Manipulating expressions with unknown variables
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=0, express a*b in terms of b alone.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
Copy of algebra.Title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about the possible number of solutions of systems of linear equations. Spoiler: There can be a single solution, zero solutions, or infinite solutions. These different cases define the distinctions between "consistent" and "inconsistent" systems, and between "dependent" and "independent" systems.
Copy of algebra.Translated Standalone Title: Number of solutions to systems of equations
Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Number of solutions to systems of equations

Copy of algebra.Description: Use everything you learned so far in order to solve any kind of system of equations!
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Solving any system of linear equations
Copy of algebra.Title: Solving any system of linear equations

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to check possible solutions of two-variable linear inequalities. For example, is (2, 0) a solution to y>x+1? In this tutorial, we also check solutions to systems of inequalities.
Copy of algebra.Title: Checking solutions of two-variable inequalities
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to check possible solutions of two-variable linear inequalities. For example, is (2, 0) a solution to y>x+1? In this tutorial, we also check solutions to systems of inequalities.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities and systems of two-variable linear inequalities.
Copy of algebra.Title: Graphing two-variable inequalities
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to graph two-variables linear inequalities and systems of two-variable linear inequalities.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to construct linear inequalities and systems of inequalities given a real-life context. Learn how to interpret such inequalities in terms of a real-life context, either algebraically or graphically.
Copy of algebra.Title: Modeling with linear inequalities
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to construct linear inequalities and systems of inequalities given a real-life context. Learn how to interpret such inequalities in terms of a real-life context, either algebraically or graphically.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+2|-8.
Copy of algebra.Title: Graphs of absolute value functions
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to graph absolute value functions like f(x)=|x+2|-8.

Copy of algebra.Description: We are used to functions that have the same rule for all inputs. For example, f(x)=x outputs the square of every input. Piecewise functions have different output rules, depending on the inputs. For example, we can define function g to output x for all positive values of x and x for all negative values of x, so g(2)=4 and g(-2)=-8.
Copy of algebra.Title: Piecewise functions
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: We are used to functions that have the same rule for all inputs. For example, f(x)=x outputs the square of every input. Piecewise functions have different output rules, depending on the inputs. For example, we can define function g to output x for all positive values of x and x for all negative values of x, so g(2)=4 and g(-2)=-8.

Copy of algebra.Description: Description
Copy of algebra.Title: Title
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Translated Description

Copy of algebra.Description: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent is an integer that can either be positive or negative.
Copy of algebra.Title: Exponent properties review
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Practice using the exponent properties to rewrite powers, where the exponent is an integer that can either be positive or negative.

Copy of algebra.Description: Radicals (also known as roots) are a generalization of square roots. They are the inverse operation of any power. For example, the 5th root of 32 is 2, because 2=32.
Copy of algebra.Title: Radicals
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Radicals (also known as roots) are a generalization of square roots. They are the inverse operation of any power. For example, the 5th root of 32 is 2, because 2=32.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn the definition for raising a number by a fractional exponent, like 8^.
Copy of algebra.Title: Rational exponents intro
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn the definition for raising a number by a fractional exponent, like 8^.

Copy of algebra.Description: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents using the properties of exponents.
Copy of algebra.Title: Properties of exponents (rational exponents)
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: In this tutorial you will rewrite variable expressions with rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

Copy of algebra.Description: Evaluate elaborate expressions that contain radicals and fractional exponents.
Copy of algebra.Title: Advanced exponent & radical evaluation
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Evaluate elaborate expressions that contain radicals and fractional exponents.

Copy of algebra.Description: We know how to evaluate square roots of perfect squares. For example, 16=4. What about the other square roots? It's harder to give an exact number, but we can simplify them so we have a better understanding of their value. For example, 32=42. Learn more about it in this tutorial.
Copy of algebra.Title: Simplifying square roots
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: We know how to evaluate square roots of perfect squares. For example, 16=4. What about the other square roots? It's harder to give an exact number, but we can simplify them so we have a better understanding of their value. For example, 32=42. Learn more about it in this tutorial.

Copy of algebra.Description: Just like we can simplify square roots, we can simplify other radicals. This tutorial covers the simplification of higher-index roots. For example, 48=23.
Copy of algebra.Title: Simplifying radicals (higher-index roots)
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Just like we can simplify square roots, we can simplify other radicals. This tutorial covers the simplification of higher-index roots. For example, 48=23.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about exponential growth and decay, and specifically how it always grows (or diminishes) by equal factors.
Copy of algebra.Title: Exponential vs. linear growth
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about exponential growth and decay, and specifically how it always grows (or diminishes) by equal factors.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to construct exponential functions to model real-world situations.
Copy of algebra.Title: Exponential expressions
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to construct exponential functions to model real-world situations.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how an exponential function behaves as the value of its input increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity. Learn how to graph basic exponential functions.
Copy of algebra.Title: Graphs of exponential growth
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how an exponential function behaves as the value of its input increases to positive infinity or decreases to negative infinity. Learn how to graph basic exponential functions.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how distinguish between linear and exponential growth, and learn the differences between the end behavior of polynomial and exponential functions.
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time
Copy of algebra.Title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how distinguish between linear and exponential growth, and learn the differences between the end behavior of polynomial and exponential functions.
Copy of algebra.Translated Standalone Title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time
Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Exponential vs. linear growth over time

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to construct exponential functions and then analyze them to model and solve real-world problems.
Copy of algebra.Title: Exponential decay
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to construct exponential functions and then analyze them to model and solve real-world problems.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to analyze the formulas of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.
Copy of algebra.Title: Exponential functions from tables & graphs
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to analyze the formulas of basic exponential functions in order to find their common ratio, initial value, and other parameters.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?
Copy of algebra.Title: Intro to polynomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about polynomial expressions: What are they? How are they constructed? What can we do with them?

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.
Copy of algebra.Title: Adding & subtracting polynomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial expressions with one variable.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables
Copy of algebra.Title: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to add and subtract polynomial that involve two variables. For example, x^3 + xy + 3y - (x^3 + 6xy + 2y^2).
Copy of algebra.Translated Standalone Title: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables
Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Adding and subtracting polynomials: two variables

Copy of algebra.Description: As an intro to more elaborate polynomial multiplication, learn how to multiply monomials (which are polynomials with a single term). For example, multiply 2x and 5x.
Copy of algebra.Title: Multiplying monomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: As an intro to more elaborate polynomial multiplication, learn how to multiply monomials (which are polynomials with a single term). For example, multiply 2x and 5x.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a monomial expression. Monomials are just polynomials with a single term!
Copy of algebra.Title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a monomial expression. Monomials are just polynomials with a single term!
Copy of algebra.Translated Standalone Title: Multiplying a monomial by a polynomial
Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Multiplying a monomial by a polynomial

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to multiply two binomials together. For example, (3x - 7) * (10x + 2).
Copy of algebra.Title: Multiplying binomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to multiply two binomials together. For example, (3x - 7) * (10x + 2).

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a binomial expression.
Copy of algebra.Title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to multiply a polynomial expression by a binomial expression.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.
Copy of algebra.Title: Special products of binomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn about the special types of products of binomials: perfect squares and the difference of two squares. These will be very helpful once you tackle more advanced expressions in Algebra.

Copy of algebra.Description: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.
Copy of algebra.Title: Polynomials word problems
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: See a few examples of how we can represent real-world situations with polynomials.

Copy of algebra.Description: Description
Copy of algebra.Title: Title
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Translated Description

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.
Copy of algebra.Title: Introduction to factorization
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn what factorization is all about, and warm-up by factoring some monomials.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to write a monomial as a factor of two other monomials. For example, write 12x^3 as (4x)(3x^2).
Copy of algebra.Title: Factoring monomials
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to write a monomial as a factor of two other monomials. For example, write 12x^3 as (4x)(3x^2).

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
Copy of algebra.Title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to take a common monomial factor out of a polynomial expression. For example, write 2x^3+6x^2+8x as (2x)(x^2+3x+4).
Copy of algebra.Translated Standalone Title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors
Copy of algebra.Standalone Title: Factoring polynomials by taking common factors

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to evaluate expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=3, evaluate 4a+4b.
Copy of algebra.Title: Evaluating expressions with unknown variables
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to evaluate expressions with variables whose values are unknown, by using another information about those variables. For example, given that a+b=3, evaluate 4a+4b.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).
Copy of algebra.Title: Factoring quadratics intro
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient of 1. For example, factor x+3x+2 as (x+1)(x+2).

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).
Copy of algebra.Title: Factoring quadratics by grouping
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to factor quadratic expressions with a leading coefficient other than 1. For example, factor 2x+7x+3 as (2x+1)(x+3).

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).
Copy of algebra.Title: Factoring polynomials with quadratic forms
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to factor quadratic polynomials of the form ax^2+bx+c as the product of two linear binomials. For example, write x^2+3x-10 as (x+5)(x-2). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate polynomials that aren't necessarily quadratic. For example, write x^4-4x^2-12 as (x^2+2)(x^2-6).

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).
Copy of algebra.Title: Factoring quadratics: Difference of squares
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "difference of squares" form. For example, write x-16 as (x+4)(x-4). Learn how to identify this form in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x-49 as (2x+7)(2x-7).

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x+6x+9 as (x+3). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x+28x+49 as (2x+7).
Copy of algebra.Title: Factoring quadratics: Perfect squares
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to factor quadratics that have the "perfect square" form. For example, write x+6x+9 as (x+3). Learn how to identify these forms in more elaborate expressions. For example, write 4x+28x+49 as (2x+7).

Copy of algebra.Description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.
Copy of algebra.Title: Strategy in factoring quadratics
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics, which apply on different occasions and conditions. Now that we know all of them, let's think strategically about which of them is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

Copy of algebra.Description: Factor polynomials of various degrees using factorization methods that are based on the special product forms "difference of squares" and "perfect squares." For example, factor 25x-30x+9 as (5x-3).
Copy of algebra.Translated Title: Factoring polynomials with special product forms

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn what parabolas are and about their main features: their general shape, vertex, and axis of symmetry.

Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn what parabolas are and about their main features: their general shape, vertex, and axis of symmetry.

Copy of algebra.Description: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.
Copy of algebra.Title: Quadratic factored form
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: The factored form of a quadratic function is an expression that is, well, factored! Like f(x)=(2x+1)(x-3). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

Copy of algebra.Description: In this tutorial you will learn about the most basic way of solving quadratic equations.

Copy of algebra.Description: The vertex form of a quadratic function shows the coordinates of the parabola's vertex. For example, the vertex of g(x)=(x-1)+2 is at (1,2). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.
Copy of algebra.Title: Quadratic vertex form
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: The vertex form of a quadratic function shows the coordinates of the parabola's vertex. For example, the vertex of g(x)=(x-1)+2 is at (1,2). Learn how to analyze functions given in this form to find their zeros, their vertex, and their graph.

Copy of algebra.Description: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.
Copy of algebra.Title: Solving quadratics by factoring
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: In this tutorial, you'll learn some pretty elaborate ways of solving quadratic equations, by harnessing the mighty strength of algebra.

Copy of algebra.Description: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.
Copy of algebra.Title: Completing the square
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: You're already familiar with factoring quadratics, but have begun to realize that it only is useful in certain cases.  Well, this tutorial will introduce you to something far more powerful and general.  Even better, it is the bridge to understanding and proving the famous quadratic formula.

Copy of algebra.Description: Learn how to solve any quadratic equation with the most general tool of all, the quadratic formula!
Copy of algebra.Title: The quadratic formula
Copy of algebra.Translated Description: Learn how to solve any quadratic equation with the most general tool of all, the quadratic formula!
